goals.question: What is the average temperature distribution in Seattle throughout the year?
goals.visualization: Line chart of average temperature by month
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the seasonal temperature changes in Seattle and identify the months with the highest and lowest temperatures.

goals.question: What is the distribution of precipitation in Seattle throughout the year?
goals.visualization: Line chart of average precipitation by month
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the seasonal precipitation changes in Seattle and identify the months with the highest and lowest precipitation levels.

goals.question: What is the relationship between temperature and humidity in Seattle?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of temperature vs humidity
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the correlation between temperature and humidity in Seattle and identify any patterns or trends.

goals.question: What is the distribution of wind speed in Seattle throughout the year?
goals.visualization: Line chart of average wind speed by month
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the seasonal wind speed changes in Seattle and identify the months with the highest and lowest wind speeds.

goals.question: What is the distribution of cloud cover in Seattle throughout the year?
goals.visualization: Line chart of average cloud cover by month
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the seasonal cloud cover changes in Seattle and identify the months with the highest and lowest cloud cover levels.

code:
```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('seattle-weather-hourly-normals.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['date_time'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date_time'], format='%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date_time'])]

# Extract month from date_time
data['month'] = data['date_time'].dt.month

# Compute average temperature by month
avg_temp_by_month = data.groupby('month')['temperature'].mean()

# Create line chart
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(avg_temp_by_month.index, avg_temp_by_month.values, color='blue')

# Add horizontal line for average temperature
avg_temp = avg_temp_by_month.mean()
ax.axhline(avg_temp, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Average temperature: {avg_temp:.2f}')

# Set chart title and axis labels
ax.set_title('What is the average temperature distribution in Seattle throughout the year?')
ax.set_xlabel('Month')
ax.set_ylabel('Average temperature (°F)')

# Set x-axis tick labels
ax.set_xticks(avg_temp_by_month.index)
ax.set_xticklabels(['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun', 'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec'])

# Add legend
ax.legend()

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('seattle-weather-hourly-normals.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['date_time'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date_time'], format='%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date_time'])]

# Extract month from date_time
data['month'] = data['date_time'].dt.month

# Calculate average precipitation by month
precipitation_by_month = data.groupby('month')['precipitation'].mean()

# Create line chart
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(precipitation_by_month.index, precipitation_by_month.values, color='blue')

# Add horizontal line for average precipitation
avg_precipitation = precipitation_by_month.mean()
ax.axhline(avg_precipitation, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Average Precipitation: {avg_precipitation:.2f} in')

# Set chart title and axis labels
ax.set_title('What is the distribution of precipitation in Seattle throughout the year?')
ax.set_xlabel('Month')
ax.set_ylabel('Precipitation (in)')

# Rotate x-axis labels
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Add legend
ax.legend()

# Show chart
plt.show()
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('seattle-weather-hourly-normals.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['date_time'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date_time'], format='%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date_time'])]

# Create scatter plot
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.scatter(data['temperature'], data['humidity'], alpha=0.5)

# Set chart title
ax.set_title('What is the relationship between temperature and humidity in Seattle?', wrap=True)

# Set axis labels
ax.set_xlabel('Temperature (F)')
ax.set_ylabel('Humidity (%)')

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('seattle-weather-hourly-normals.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['date_time'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date_time'], format='%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date_time'])]

# Extract month from date_time
data['month'] = data['date_time'].dt.month

# Group by month and calculate average wind speed
avg_wind_speed_by_month = data.groupby('month')['wind_speed'].mean()

# Create line chart
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(avg_wind_speed_by_month.index, avg_wind_speed_by_month.values, color='blue')

# Add horizontal line for average wind speed
avg_wind_speed = avg_wind_speed_by_month.mean()
ax.axhline(avg_wind_speed, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Average Wind Speed: {avg_wind_speed:.2f}')

# Set chart title and axis labels
ax.set_title('What is the distribution of wind speed in Seattle throughout the year?')
ax.set_xlabel('Month')
ax.set_ylabel('Average Wind Speed (mph)')

# Rotate x-axis labels
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Add legend
ax.legend()

# Show chart
plt.show()
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('seattle-weather-hourly-normals.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['date_time'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date_time'], format='%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date_time'])]

# Extract month from date_time
data['month'] = data['date_time'].dt.month

# Calculate average cloud cover by month
avg_cloud_cover = data.groupby('month')['cloud_cover'].mean()

# Create line chart
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(avg_cloud_cover.index, avg_cloud_cover.values, color='blue')

# Add horizontal line for average cloud cover
avg_cloud_cover_mean = avg_cloud_cover.mean()
ax.axhline(avg_cloud_cover_mean, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Average cloud cover: {avg_cloud_cover_mean:.2f}')

# Set chart title and axis labels
ax.set_title('What is the distribution of cloud cover in Seattle throughout the year?')
ax.set_xlabel('Month')
ax.set_ylabel('Average cloud cover')

# Rotate x-axis labels
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Add legend
ax.legend()

plt.show()
```

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('seattle-weather-hourly-normals.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['date_time'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date_time'], format='%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['date_time'])]

# Extract month from date_time
data['month'] = data['date_time'].dt.month

# Calculate average cloud cover by month
avg_cloud_cover = data.groupby('month')['cloud_cover'].mean()

# Create line chart
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(avg_cloud_cover.index, avg_cloud_cover.values, color='blue')

# Add horizontal line for average cloud cover
avg_cloud_cover_mean = avg_cloud_cover.mean()
ax.axhline(avg_cloud_cover_mean, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Average cloud cover: {avg_cloud_cover_mean:.2f}')

# Set chart title and axis labels
ax.set_title('What is the distribution of cloud cover in Seattle throughout the year?')
ax.set_xlabel('Month')
ax.set_ylabel('Average cloud cover')

# Rotate x-axis labels
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Add legend
ax.legend()

plt.show()
